sentence: Shares of Microsoft (MSFT) are higher by 58 cents, or 0.6%, at $92.40, after Canaccord Genuity's Richard Davis offered up a scenario in which the newer parts of the company's business, such as its "Office 365" online suite, become a larger and larger part of its total revenue, pushing the company's market capitalization above one trillion dollars.

"If you believe, as we do, that it is reasonable to expect MSFT to appreciate between 10-20% annually for the next five years, you get to the Big T as early as calendar Q4 2019, or more like sometime in early 2020," writes Davis.
Davis's note, which involved spending over two weeks to "disaggregate and reassemble the firm's somewhat opaque income statement," has echoes of a note yesterday by Christopher Eberle of Instinet.
Like Eberle, Davis identifies multiple areas of the business that are coming of age under CEO Satya Nadella.
They include Office 365 but also "an emerging CRM/marketing suite versus Salesforce (CRM), strong demand tailwinds for the Xbox franchise, and a public cloud platform in Azure."

Davis's contention is that even if older parts of the business, such as traditional Windows software, decline by something intense, like 10% per annum, "the combined revenue from the aforementioned growth segments will simply become a bigger percentage of total revenue sooner."

And even as Microsoft spends money to build Office 365 and " Dynamics," its back-office suite, and others, "scale eventually overwhelms spend, and that pushes margins higher, sometimes in a discontinuously positive direction."

And that means that investors will gravitate to Microsoft's profitability:

Finally, even though the overall stock market is in bull market rally mode, we have been around long enough to realize that investor sentiment changes much faster than companies can change their business models.

This sentiment shift almost always means a greater emphasis on the here and now, which financially means that investors shift their funds into companies that are making money today, rather than speeders who hope to someday do so.
Therefore, we view the fact that MSFT generates ~31% Free Cash Flow margins and is valued at 19x EV/FCF as a cushion against the time when the tide washes out - and it will someday.
As for the moment, Davis counsels some degree of caution on the stock given a 20% or so run since October.
"We would use this possible pullback to refill that position," he writes, "because we are quite bullish intermediate and long-term."
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
